The last Benedictine nuns to serve Deadwood, South Dakota retired this month, leaving the South Dakota gambling town without their presence for the first time in more than a century.
Jim Kent visited with Sisters Grace and Maureen at St. Martin Monastery, their new home 30 miles away in Rapid City.
Tradition says that on any given day, Deadwood's narrow streets were filled with gunslingers, gamblers, gold prospectors, women of questionable character, and Catholic nuns.
That's right.
Benedictine nuns road into town from Switzerland in 1898 in the wake of they typhoid epidemic, established St. Joseph's Hospital, and never left.
Well, at least not until this year.

At 90, she's been a Benedictine for more than 70 years.
